short_description_en: Detects domestic abuse in healthcare settings.
medium_description_en: Detects domestic abuse (intimate partner violence) in pregnant and nonpregnant women in healthcare settings.

input_schema.name: one
input_schema.label_en: Have you ever been emotionally or physically abused by your partner or someone important to you?

input_schema.name: two
input_schema.label_en: Within the last year, have you been hit, slapped, kicked, or otherwise physically hurt by your partner or someone important to you?

input_schema.name: three
input_schema.label_en: Within the last year, has anyone forced you to have sexual activities?

input_schema.name: four
input_schema.label_en: Are you afraid of your partner or any one of the following: husband/wife, ex-husband/ex-wife, boyfriend/girlfriend, stranger?

input_schema.name: five
input_schema.label_en: If pregnant, have you been hit, slapped, kicked, or otherwise physically hurt by your partner or someone important to you during your pregnancy?

about.more_info_en: A “yes” answer to any of the screening questions is considered a positive screening result.

Validation.text: Norton LB, Peipert JF, Zierler S, Lima B, Hume L. Battering in pregnancy: an assessment of two screening methods. Obstet Gynecol. 1995;85(3):321-325.

Feltner C, Wallace I, Berkman N, et al. Screening for intimate partner violence, elder abuse, and abuse of vulnerable adults: evidence report and systematic review for the US preventive services task force. JAMA. 2018;320(16):1688.

Original/Primary Reference.text: McFarlane J, Parker B, Soeken K, Bullock L. Assessing for abuse during pregnancy. Severity and frequency of injuries and associated entry into prenatal care. JAMA. 1992;267(23):3176-3178.

creator_info.about_en: Judith McFarlane, DrPH, RN, is a professor of nursing at Texas Woman’s University in Houston, TX. She also works with UNICEF in Zimbabwe to measure the impact of micro-finance and was selected as a consultant for a gender based violence prevention initiative in Africa and Asia. Dr. McFarlane’s primary research is focused on the health effects of violence against women and children and the effectiveness of interventions to prevent further violence.
